comments.commentBody:
The BCS Championship has become a Joke; Boycott it to make them change it!
I’m a football fan and I’m a BIG SEC FAN but I can’t agree with this.
At best, this is the true 2011 SEC Football Championship Game not the 2011 National Championship Football Game. Is this what championship football on the field means? Or are Poll & Computer opinions most important in determining a BCS participant?
If you want to see a real college football playoff, boycott the BCS Championship Game on ESPN.
Please don’t watch it on ESPN or go to a Sport Bar to watch it on ESPN, or listen to it on ESPN radio or go online at ESPN.com. Believe me I love ESPN but I just watched the BCS Selection Show and they all have become apologists for our lack of a legitimate college football playoff system.
Do you really think Disney, ESPN, the Advertisers, the Major Conferences and the Brewers & Sports Bars will take a 50% drop in viewership lightly? Not when there is millions of $ involved to get you to watch!
Clearly, the only people who can end this farce of a BCS National Championship are we the people.
If you’re upset, do something, Pass this on; we need a lot of people not to watch this game.
For what it’s worth my recommended Playoff; the top 8 rated teams (6 Major Conference Champions and two highest rated at-large teams) are invited to play in the Cotton Bowl, Orange Bowl, Rose Bowl and Sugar Bowl, (let’s try to keep a little tradition).
With all due respect, Stanford is not the better team over Oregon.

I believe you misunderstood the saying in the 90s. Gingrich et al had a Contract with America in 1994, to combat what was going on, i.e. Clinton's Contract against America (don't you remember the huge Clinton-Gore tax increase of 1993, the largest in history; and the hated, Democrat-designed "Hillarycare?)
Scholarships to most Ivy League schools are based upon need of the applicant. Wouldn't you reason, then, that the poor get the scholarships? (Currently at Harvard, a student admitted whose family makes $65,000 or less is given a free ride).
Morally bankrupt? Wouldn't that be Obama, who cut out the charter school program for disadvantaged students in Washington, D.C., and sent his own children to an expensive private school?
How, pray tell, do you know about the work and life experience of Newt Gingrich?
And she shamelessly applied for social security...  Like most ideologues she was more talk than walk.
As if anyone possessing a sound mind would want someone even loosely following Ayn Rand.

I do not see how given the obvious prevarications you just pointed out, Romney can be considered qualified to be president. If you have to lie, to undermine your opponent, that shows you have nothing of substance to offer in his place.

It would seem to me that anyone running against Romney would make this an issue. As for Gingrich, his "Contract with America" was more derisively known as his "Contract on America.' His latest little peccadillo shows just how morally bankrupt he is. Some of the hardest working people I ever saw were the teenage children of migrant (legal and illegal) working alongside their families in the orchards. And we have seen some of them, who despite their disadvantaged economic position, received scholarships to Ivy League Schools.

It is also obvious Gingrich has never been on a factory floor, or followed a plant electrician around for a full day. He has no idea what a working person does for that matter.

The other Republican hopefuls seem to have shot themselves in the foot except for Huntsman. That leaves Ron Paul, whom many consider to be the true Libertarian, but he is in fact a pseudo Libertarian. He makes it look like he is a follower of Ayn Rand, but he hedges his position;, he is not a consistent follower; and only takes the ideas he thinks will sell. That also shows a lack of moral courage. You either accept her whole package, or in her eyes, you were just playing mind games with yourself.

I don't see anything Judaic here, this is a straight rip from Levant or East Mediterranean iconography. "mandate-era"? You mean Palestine? Is it so painful to say that word? The checkered Keffiyah pattern is Palestinian, Arab, Levant, nothing Israeli at all. No amount of David's stars can change that.

There are few things that show less self-respect than no hosiery on the legs. What? Are is there a perpetual picnic going on? Please cover your legs so that you don't look always immediately "available". And given the age of these women, a bit of decorum isn't a bad thing. Didn't Carrie Bradshaw create enough women with, ahem, social shall-we-say "memories" of nameless sex?
It looks like she has a big Seattle-grunge beard.
Mmm, one day in a closed room or a lifetime thrashing against a closed mind - I know who's son I'd rather be!
The Bacammon board what the best looking thing I saw; everything else was tasteless or ugly.

Gorgeous and the reason for the comments dis'ing it is essentially the ignorance by most Americans about art. This is art. Luscious design and music and th 'faceless' models and mannequins are righteous as they force the viewer to see the figure and design as sculpture more than fashion. Fabulous - and a next step suggestion which would be an improvement: the artists invited to participate should be broadened. Invite a couple of filmmakers (how about an animator.. I did an animated film re this and would love to collaborate with these folks), and some of the remarkable traditional musicians that have been doing this for literally years. The history of Jewish instrumental music is comprised of such marriages (because artists and musicians always have ignored and gone around and below such boundaries).

I am happy that they are sharing fashion technology.
Can they share solar technology, can they share water, land,
an economic development bank? Can the fashion show
also discuss Martin Buber's ideas about how to have a liberatory
society?

Funny statement:  “There is just a small pool of candidates who possess the skill set that is required and are willing to take on the stressful 24/7 nature of the position.” Seems that we have no trouble finding candidates for President of the United States for less than half the salary of the highest paid college presidents. So it couldn't be the 24/7 stress that keeps that candidate pool small.

From Dr W:



Transit Times for Different Parabolic Slide Paths
"No one ever went broke underestimating the intelligence of the American People"

I went to the local outlet of a large national department store chain yesterday, in search of a particular toy for a particular youngster.  I became depressed the moment I drove in the parking lot.  (It happens to me every time I go there, so I try my best to avoid the place.)  I look around at the people, the junk they're wearing, the junk they're buying, the junk from which they have to choose, and I get depressed.  These are the voters, this is the world in which they live, and they'll go home and sit in front of their big TV's and the mind benders will continue their mind bending to make them all think it's normal and moral and right.

First, there are plenty of "true believers" who vote Democrat because (A) they believe socialism is the answer and/or (B) they want free stuff from the government.  Second, you need to differentiate between Republicans and conservatives.  In individual cases they are the same thing, but in far too many cases they are not.  True conservatives are left with having to vote for the GOP candidate.  As to cluelessness, that personifies the first group I described because they believe the Democrats are their ticket to anything but more of the same economy-busting policies that have failed in Western Europe and are now failing here as well.  All systems are prone to corruption, including socialism.  That's because human beings are involved.  Far better to choose the system that offers the most individual liberty, and then clean up the corruption as necessary.

Alas, broad swaths of the American voting public appear to be clueless. It is to them that this farce is played. They are the true believers. They are the ones demanding these candidates, and they are the ones with the power of the vote.

True, there are knowledgeable, intellectual Republicans, but most of them are rich and want to stay that way, even if the rest of the country goes down in flames. They may not all believe in Evolution, but they all understand "survival of the fittest" and see themselves as among the most fit.

At least, that is how I see it. I'd love to find out that I'm wrong in this case.

So we're supposed to suck it up and accept that missed calls are part of the game, but how can't a Giants fan come away from today's game thinking they just watched a mid-'90s Knicks-Bulls game? So Jacquan Williams interfered on what would have been a big loss; so Donald Driver did catch that pass that was moving around in his fingertips and that he was trying to grasp when it was knocked from his hands; and so Ballard's knee didn't somehow land inbounds like the replay showed. In the very least, the Fox announcers could admit as much. If it isn't Brady, it's Brees or Rodgers. Stop with the jock-sniffing Buck and Aikman!

Thank you both for a such a brutally honest look into the life of the enforcer. What has stayed with me from part 2 is the anxiety of the future fight looking ahead on the schedule - the sleepless nights and the weight of the expectations...
So, Todd, what is your current thinking on the place of fighting in the game at this point and do you foresee a time ahead where the NHL says "No" to it all?

Thanks for the eye-opening look.

So you're saying don't treat pain appropriately because some people become addicted? Millions of people are treated successfully (and appropriately) with opioids and do not become drug addicts. The best way to prevent illicit use of these medications is to remove the DEA and criminal justice system from the equation. Take away the stigma of "addiction", and let the physicians treat the pain appropriately with the medication required; educate the patient that there will likely be a "dependency", but this is not addiction. Dependency can be easily managed medically by weaning off of the substance, but I think this part is all too often ignored because docs are constantly in fear of DEA so at the first hint of "addiction" (which usually is dependency instead), the docs tend to cut off the prescription suddenly. This leads to doctor-shopping and compulsive, secretive use, when all the patient needed was to be pre-educated, monitored and weaned. The system is screwed, not the meds.

Anyone can buy alcohol, but the use and abuse of Rx drugs starts with physicians willing to prescribe them. Is anyone looking into that? Most professional sports teams have doctors who are known to prescribe narcotics to players. Cutting those drugs off at the source would be one good way to go after this kind of substance abuse problem. A doctor's job is not to patch someone up so they can go out and injure themselves- or someone else- again.

It turns out that Reyes is as much a b.s. artist as the Met front office. There is no obligation to take every piece of bread off the table. I disdain everyone involved in this debacle--the Mets, Reyes and--yes--the Marlins which investigators are learning hid revenue sharing money the last few years to secure public funding for their new stadium and horde the funds necessary to make this big splash. Right now, I'm not feeling too warm and fuzzy about professional sports, or big-time college sports for that matter.
Is there any value to being inclusive of Islamic gender apartheid?  I mean the idea that women should be invisible to all but the men that own them should offend anyone born after the 18th century.

Pathetic misuse of furs and leather ... It is always over-reaching to have to depend on fur, especially, to draw attention, or make your "fashion statement:. Fur belongs on the sentient creatures for whom it was intended, not for some insecure "oh look at me" fashion wanna-be and the people, like Kors, who play to their insecurities.

lol
there is nothing Islamic in this show lol Muslim women never ever dress like this.

I'm perplexed as to why this is newsworthy. While there may be deep conflicts between Israel and the Islamic world, Israel is a pluralist society with diverse opinions. There is no shortage of pro-Arabic attitudes in Israel and no shortage of Israelis who wish to reach across the aisle. When there is a similar outreach from the Arabic and greater Islamic world, then it may be newsworthy. Could you even imagine a similar joint Islamic-Christian (much less Islamic-Jewish) display of cultural appreciation anywhere in the Islamic world?

How do you "meld" the 2 cultures that have so much distinction and individulality? I find the attempt inspiring, maybe courageous? However, there are so many pitfalls and traps, it's intractable.

Sure cultures evolve (maybe devolve as well). There is a singular and immutable meme that gets passed from generations and I think it's almost impossible to do this. But, a heroic attempt.

Hmm.

For most of the day, the Jets continued to be their own worst enemy. We've seen the result of that behavior when they play good teams. I shudder to think what the collective won/loss record is of the teams they've beaten vs. the teams they've lost to.

In other words, these Jets are mediocre, barely beating bad teams, getting handled by the good teams.

Should they beat KC? Of course. The Eagles in Philly? Should, but a healthy Vick might change that. Giants? Well, it will be a Jets crowd, sort of, but still a tough draw. Dolphins? With the momentum the Fins have suddenly found, who wants to test them at their place in a "win to get in" game?

11-5 is likely necessary to get in, especially since the Jets lose every imaginable tiebreaker to the teams they're competing with. So the real question is, as Rex acknowledges, can they get better?

And can they get better enough to beat the teams they have left? One stumble anywhere along the way likely ends the chase.

Do the Jets have the natural ability to be that better team? They do. Do they have the coaching talent to bring that out? I believe they do, but that's not a given. The coaching staff does need to change how they do things, because the way they've done things so far has led them here, to a team which too often adds an unnecessary difficulty factor. In the NFL, the difference between good and bad is too slim to allow it to be made slimmer by your own boo-boos.

My gut tells me we miss the dance this year.

Fully encasing a woman in a sarcophagus of fabric in order to pander to someone's sense of religious identity & moral rectitude is vile & obscene no matter how much effort is put into prettifying the result. It doesn't make it any less an assassination of womanhood. It, in fact, only bolsters the moral & social control of women as objects.

If everyone who wrote something and was able to get those thoughts published 'on the internet', was doing a reasonable amount of analytical thinking/reasoning and interested then in publishing something that was somewhat 'though out', we might be able to consider what anyone can find on the internet 'knowledge/information'. But, a simple sixty second purview of that proposal lends a different perspective to the simply stated claim that there is a greater abundance of 'information/knowledge' available on the internet than there is available an un-quantifiable amount of not particularly well thought through opinion available. Even when that opinion is flogged off as fact/knowledge/information by the so called 'experts'. And maybe this was just at true in proportion in the time of Seneca with the available resources for getting 'something' published.
